channel.title: Whats the implement for?

item.title: Whats the implement for?
item.dc:creator: @Tico135 Tico
item.description:
@Tico135 wrote:

LeScape basically got it right, but anyways, when you implement something, you are declaring the methods are linked. So let’s use a Java program example.

[code]
public class TeachingIxl implements ActionListener { // We are implementing ActionListener
public static void main(String[] args) {
new TeachingIxl();
}
private JButton button; // Basic Java object

    public TeachingIxl() {
            button = new JButton("Button");
            button.addActionListener(this); //We are declaring action to our object

    }

public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent event) {
        Object source = event.getSource();
                  if(source == button){
                  //statements here
                  }
    }

}[/code]
Hopefully that made some sense, the actionPerformed(ActionEvent event) is the method in which is being implemented.

Read full topic

item.title: Whats the implement for?
item.dc:creator: @newbiehacker newbiehacker
item.description:
@newbiehacker wrote:

Basically, the implements keyword is used to implement an interface (or interfaces)

Such as public class MyClass implements MyInterface, MyOtherInterface…

It’s basically a sort of prototype, if you will, for defining methods that the class will contain and is used often for registering your class as a member of such an interface.

For example, if I had an event-based program and I allowed plugins, then I would create a Plugin interface that all plugins could then implement.

For example

public interface Plugin {
  // Returns the author of the plugin
  String getAuthor();
  
  // Runs this plugin
  void run();
}

Then ALL classes that implement the Plugin interface HAVE to override these methods in order to compile correctly, a good example of a working plugin would be:

public class MyPlugin implements Plugin {
  public String getAuthor() {
    return "newbiehacker";
  }

  public void run() {
    System.out.println("OMG, I'M RUNNING NOW");
  }
}

I hope this helps.

Read full topic

item.title: Whats the implement for?
item.dc:creator: @LeScape LeScape
item.description:
@LeScape wrote:

Implementing an interface allows a class to become more formal about the behavior it promises to provide.
It's kind of like pre-defining how you're going to change it...I doubt it's ever going to be of any use to private servers, inheritance is all you'll need as far as connecting classes like that goes.

Read full topic

item.title: Whats the implement for?
item.dc:creator: @LeScape LeScape
item.description:
@LeScape wrote:

The implements keyword connects the class ACMEBicycle to the list of empty methods defined in:

interface Bicycle {

       void changeCadence(int newValue);

       void changeGear(int newValue);

       void speedUp(int increment);

       void applyBrakes(int decrement);
}

Read full topic
